author: nc1234
content:
> also, can this flag be gamed in anyway? like a malicious EL always setting the flag to true? this seems like a bit of a far fetched assumption though. 
You kinda need to trust your EL client because as a CL have no visibility of the tx pool on EL side. I mean similar thing today when you pass a payload to EL to verify by calling engine_newPayload, you need to trust your EL saying whether this payload is valid or not.

author: nc1234
content:
> since CL will get different flag status depending upon which EL it hooks up to. i.e. geth says true but reth says false. or maybe nbd?
Even two different machines running the same geth version can give different status because of network condition, hardware etc. So you can't really tell. You can always verify source code and build from source if concerned.

author: potuz
content: The EL is trusted, there's no "malicious" EL in the picture. If it can be gamed it could be by builders or users trying to grieve builders. For example sending txs so that the EL responds with yes when a specific builder has won the auction. So the heuristic shouldn't be stupid enough. Having multiple heuristics varying by client helps to prevent builders gaming them
